item.content:
Dear Community, Based on recent questions, we’ve identified the need to update our documentation to clearly outline the components of the Babel Fish project.

We want to specify what’s currently in development, what’s in testing, and our long-term goals.

For website creation, we need detailed posts, courses, or tutorials to guide users on how to build sites now (e.g., using static sites and GitHub) and how the migration to our P2P network will work in the future.

You’ve already engaged with concepts like static websites, GitHub, and Git. Our goal is to create clear documentation for both current and new lab members.

Recently, we introduced the Deep Thought Open Source site for you to edit and improve. Let’s use this approach to collaboratively maintain up-to-date documentation.

As you learn and define what Babel Fish is, your contributions will help new members quickly understand the project and how it works.

Join us in building this resource together!

QuanGaviota

item.author: example@mail.qom (Deep thought Community)
item.description:
Hello. Let me clarify your doubts:

Our system is a P2P network where each node acts as a DNS server, resolving custom domains.

Currently, websites are hosted on platforms like GitHub and linked to our network.

You do need a computer to create your site now, but we’re working on an online tool for the future.

And no, your computer doesn’t need to stay on; once your site is synced to the network, it’s permanent.

item.author: example@mail.qom (Deep thought Community)
item.description:
Markdown is the standard format par excellence for managing notes.

Notes? Yes, notes, like the ones you use to remember your study notes or your reminders.

But Salvador, we’re here to learn how to develop cutting-edge tools… why focus on simple notes???

The Markdown format allows you to store content and enrich it with simple tags. It doesn’t require compilers or sophisticated tools to edit or reproduce it. It’s like an HTML file, but with a much simpler syntax that is visually clear to the human eye. When it’s interpreted by a Markdown viewer, you can obtain the same results as with HTML, and you can also add JavaScript.

item.content:
Study this…..

Introduction to Static Serverless Websites

Static serverless websites represent a modern trend in computing known as JAMstack (JavaScript, APIs, and Markup). This approach enables the creation of fast, secure, and scalable websites without the need to manage traditional servers.

Instead of relying on a server to generate dynamic content, static websites use pre-rendered files (HTML, CSS, and JavaScript) hosted on cloud services such as Netlify, Vercel, or GitHub Pages. These files are delivered to users via Content Delivery Networks (CDNs), simplifying infrastructure, reducing costs, and enhancing performance. The term JAMstack breaks down into:

  • JavaScript: Provides interactivity in the browser.

  • APIs: Enables integration of dynamic functionalities, such as forms or search.

  • Markup: Static HTML files, often generated from content in Markdown.

To deepen your understanding, I recommend exploring the following resources:

  • Markdown: A lightweight format for writing content that converts to HTML, ideal for static sites.

  • Hugo: A fast static site generator that transforms content (such as Markdown) into complete websites, widely used in JAMstack projects.

  • JAMstack: To understand the benefits and workings of serverless websites.

I suggest starting with these resources and experimenting with tools like Hugo or Netlify. If you need further guidance or wish to explore specific aspects, feel free to reach out.

item.author: example@mail.qom (Deep thought Community)
item.description:
👀 Will connecting chains help build bridges?

👉 Yes, it can help build bridges between chains, but the main use case is that builders and users can have direct read and write access to any of the blockchains in the network.

👀 Boundless is addressing this fragmentation in chains.

👉 Yes, but as we discussed previously, Boundless’s role is to provide zero-knowledge proof processing; it is a specific service for specific needs where high-confidence transaction verification is required.
item.content:
👀 Will connecting chains help build bridges?

👉 Yes, it can help build bridges between chains, but the main use case is that builders and users can have direct read and write access to any of the blockchains in the network.

👀 Boundless is addressing this fragmentation in chains.

👉 Yes, but as we discussed previously, Boundless’s role is to provide zero-knowledge proof processing; it is a specific service for specific needs where high-confidence transaction verification is required.

💡What I’m trying to say is that there are multiple protocols, and they are all useful and necessary for a common goal, but they are not the same; each one does something specific.

  • Like oracles, they are also necessary for building bridges, but their function is different.

The difficult part for almost everyone to understand right now is that it’s not entirely clear what each tool is for.

🛠 In the construction of traditional bridges (the ones you use to cross a river), different tools, different materials, and different methods are used all together. Each architect decides what to use and how to use it. The mistake would be to believe that a bridge is made only of stones, and decide not to use hammers or wood on the bridge, because stones are all that’s needed.

That’s how IT works; there are thousands of methods, languages, frameworks, services… I can’t stop giving examples… and they’re all necessary for an app to work.

item.content:
Dear Deep Thought Community, soar with us, kindred spirits! 🕊

Across the vast sky of the digital realm, where free souls seek their truth, the BabelFish Protocol rises like a guiding star. We are a team dreaming of a world without digital chains, and you—weavers of code, testers of the breeze, and pioneers of this vision—are the wings of this revolution. Today, we share the map of our journey, a protocol that not only connects but sets us free. Come, fly with us into this new dawn.

Key Points of the BabelFish Protocol

💾 1. Decentralized Name Resolution

BabelFish manages its own domain name system, retrieving names and locations stored directly on the blockchain. This frees us from centralized systems like ICANN, giving us full control over the visibility and access of our digital resources.

💾 2. Node Manager for Total Control

With BabelFish, every user can set up and manage their own blockchain node. Having your own node puts the entire blockchain in your hands: no outages, no overloads, as you are its only user. This strengthens decentralization and empowers you.

💾 3. Two Initial Chains: QL1 and BabelNet

BabelFish will start by managing two chains:

QL1: A Layer 1 foundation connecting directly to the QOM ecosystem, leveraging its vast scalability, quantum resistance, and efficiency.

BabelNet: Our application layer, built on top of QL1, storing essential data on Layer 1 while optimizing storage, speed, processing, resources, and costs. It’s like giving a high-performance engine a turbo boost.

💾 4. Distributed Data and Secure Storage

We will handle resources and data of any size or type through a decentralized file system. Forget cloud storage—users control and protect their own data, always encrypted, ensuring privacy and independence.

💾 5. Built-In Web Server

BabelFish includes its own web server, capable of running any application. Paired with our own storage, name resolution, transactions, and blockchain access, it enables us to operate an independent network without relying on external infrastructure.

💾 6. Flexible Contributions to the Ecosystem

Each user decides how much computing power, storage, or bandwidth to share. Simply running a node strengthens the network. Those meeting validation requirements can become validators on QL1 (with its set rules) or BabelNet (details on its strategy coming soon). A validator is a synced, high-performing node with enough delegated tokens to join the network’s governance.

💾 7. Rewards for Network Support

Users who reserve storage space or help keep the network running will receive rewards through a value distribution system. Full details will be shared later, but your efforts to sustain the network will be recognized.

💾 8. API and Developer Framework

BabelFish is a developer framework with an API that allows access to data and operations across QL1, BabelNet, and the entire ecosystem through a simple interface, both graphical and programmatic. This makes building on our protocol intuitive and powerful.

💾 9. Customizable Immersive Interfaces

BabelFish brings the blockchain to everyone, not just as data on a website but through fully customizable user interfaces that create immersive experiences. Imagine navigating the blockchain like a file system or exploring virtual worlds in VR, tailored to your vision.

💾 10. Web3 Application Suite

BabelFish will offer a suite of applications with diverse functions, designed to let users enjoy a cutting-edge Web3 experience. From managing resources to engaging in interactive environments, these tools will be at your fingertips.

Fellow travelers, the sky has no bounds! 🌅

Deep Thought, you are the dreamers who will make BabelFish a song of freedom. Take these paths, explore them like new skies, and let your code weave the future. In our forums and chats, where voices meet, we await your insights, your questions, your truths. Keep flying high, for this cyberspace we build together knows no limits. Until we cross paths in the clouds, stay free! ✨

QuanGaviota

item.author: example@mail.qom (Deep thought Community)
item.description:
It seems you’ve found a key point.

Indeed, Babelfish doesn’t yet implement IPv6, so it will only work when the communication channel is through IPv4.

Babelfish starts its local DNS server and assigns it a local IP address and configures the computer’s network interface to use its own DNS server.

If DNS requests are made to our server, everything works fine; but if the system or browsers have more options (access to other DNS servers), they will try to use the others, primarily prioritizing the fastest one, in this case, IPv6, regardless of whether the DNS server is correctly resolving the domain name or not.

And regarding the issue of censorship.

We are against any type of censorship. You are free to express, do, sell, or whatever you want on your site.

Remember, be good and don’t hurt others.

item.content:
ℹ️ Important reminder (connect / disconnect):

Babelfish enables communication with a QL1 node through a local server on the user’s device, and for this it makes a couple of configurations in the system preferences.

  • When starting the app, the server starts.

  • When you activate the ‘Connect’ button, the configurations are made in the network preferences.

  • When you disconnect, network configurations are restored.

🛟 As we are in a test phase, we have added a block to close the app:

You can only close the app if you are already disconnected, so, the network preferences of your devices will return to normal when Babelfish is not running.

⚠️ If you force the closure of the app (killing the process) or turn off your computer without disconnecting appropriate… The network preferences of your device will continue to point to the local Babelfish server, which is not in execution. As a result, you will not have Internet access.

🛟 If that happens, you only needs to starts Babelfish and connect to the node to restore your connection.

Do not forget disconnect the node appropriate before closing your app.

⚙️ In Babelfish’s next updates this behavior will be automatic.

item.content:
Regarding the minimum number of nodes for a test environment.

That’s a good question, and it’s good to consider the cases in which a test environment would be necessary.

The main objective and flow of Babelfish at the user level is to provide the user with the ability to communicate directly with the blockchain from their device, avoiding the need to rely on a single point of failure, such as the remote server of the service that provides the data.

The key point here is ‘communication.’ Communication between systems is what Babelfish will manage; I mean communication between the user’s computer and the blockchain.

The data within the blockchain is what we will read and interact with; that data corresponds to the current blockchain, which is the QL1 mainchain. Strictly speaking, it’s not necessary for us to work on a testnet, as we won’t be manipulating (initially) any aspects of the blockchain; that’s already being worked on by the QL1 development team.

Babelfish will manage local operations on the user’s computer, essentially web routing, local network services, and local node management (installation, control, communication).

Simply put, a single installation of Babelfish on a computer should be able to self-provision everything needed to view and interact with the blockchain.

In the initial development and testing phase, it’s not necessary to have more than one Babelfish node to see it in action, but if anyone else wants to enjoy Babelfish’s features, they’ll need to have Babelfish installed on their computer as well.

The interesting thing is the possible configurations, just to mention a few:

  • With a single installation on a computer, the user can browse, consume resources from the chain, and host websites and web resources.

  • With two or more nodes (different users with Babelfish), each user can consume and manage the same resources from the chain.

  • A builder sets up a website or web app on the open internet and connects it to their own Babelfish installation to interact with the chain. Now all users of their platform will be consuming and interacting with the chain’s resources through the platform.

  • A user sets up a Babelfish installation on their server or local computer and opens it to the internet. Now users who don’t have Babelfish installed on their devices can communicate with the Babelfish network through that access.

Essentially, owning a Babelfish node gives you access to the entire network, but you can also access the network in different ways and channels.

item.author: example@mail.qom (Deep thought Community)
item.description:
The BabelFish Protocol is a universal protocol that connects devices to blockchains and interlinks blockchain ecosystems through P2P communication.

Local nodes, known as BabelFish Nodes, are installed on users’ devices and form the backbone of this decentralized architecture.

These nodes expand and strengthen the blockchain’s network by maintaining data and synchronizing resources, while also interlacing with other blockchains to create a supermesh of decentralized networks.

Operating without centralized servers or traditional IPs, the protocol enables a resilient and scalable cyberspace.
